courses.course_description: Current and new developments in nuclear engineering.
courses.prerequisites: sophomore standing; PHYSCS 1210 and PHYSCS 1220 and MATH 1100 or MATH 1120 or instructor's consent

courses.course_name: Harnessing the Atoms in Everyday Life: Fulfill M Curie's Dream
courses.course_description: Introduction to applications of nuclear science and technology, utilizing web-based learning scenarios.
Current and new developments in nuclear engineering.  May be repeated for credit.

Introduction of methods and procedures for safe handling of radioisotopes in the research laboratory. Intensive lecture and laboratory training sessions designed for persons planning to use radioisotopes at the University.

(same as RA_SCI 4303) Types and origins of radiation; radiation detection and measurement; radiation interactions; shielding; dose calculations; federal, state and local regulations; and procedures for safe uses of radiation. Laboratory experiments in radiation measurements and protection.

Introductory topics in nuclear engineering. Atomic and nuclear physics; nuclear reactor principles under steady-state and transient conditions; heat removal; shielding; instrumentation; power generation; fusion.

(same as CH_ENG 4306; cross-leveled with NU_ENG 7306). Applies ordinary and partial differential equations to engineering problems; Fourier's series; determinants and matrices; Laplace transforms; analog computer techniques.

(same as ECE 4020). Analysis of present energy usage in Missouri, USA and the world, evaluation of emerging energy technologies and trends for the future. Economics and environmental impact of the developed technologies.

courses.course_name: Energy Systems and Resources - Writing Intensive
courses.course_description: (same as ECE 4020). Analysis of present energy usage in Missouri, USA and the world, evaluation of emerging energy technologies and trends for the future. Economics and environmental impact of the developed technologies.

(same as PHYSCS 4190,  BIOL_EN 4480 and CHEM 4490). Undergraduate/graduate level course offered every winter semester for students from Physics, Chemistry, Engineering and Medical Departments and consists of lectures, laboratory demonstrations, two mid term and one final exam. Graduate students will submit a term paper.
courses.prerequisites: PHYSCS 2760 and CHEM 1320 or equivalent and instructor's consent

courses.course_description: Not for engineering students. Lecture, demonstration; describes physical environment, energy, power plants, nuclear reactors; radioactivity, its biological effects; health physics measures, rad-waste disposal; nuclear safeguards, nuclear explosives, societal implications.
(same as BIO_SC 4328, RADIOL 4328, V_M_S 7328). Concepts of ionizing radiations, their actions on matter through effects on simple chemical systems, biological molecules, cell, organisms, man.
courses.prerequisites: junior standing, Sciences/Engineering; one course in Biological Sciences and Physics/Chemistry; or instructor's consent

courses.course_name: Science and Technology of Terrorism and Counter Terrorism
courses.course_description: (same as PEA_ST 4330). Terrorism has been a familiar tool of political conflict, and it has assumed greater importance during the past twenty years. This subject has been treated by political scientists in various forms, but the scientific and technological aspects of different forms of terrorism cannot be found in a single place. It is important for persons who propose counter measures to understand the basics of different types of terrorism such as for instance the nature of chemical agents, their properties such as toxicity, etc. in order to build better defense systems.

courses.course_name: Nonproliferation Issues for Weapons of Mass Destruction
courses.course_description: Nonproliferation and impact on technology and world events.
courses.prerequisites: junior/senior standing or instructor's consent.  May be repeated for credit

courses.course_name: Nonproliferation Issues for Weapons of Mass Destruction - Writing Intensive
courses.course_description: Nonproliferation and impact on technology and world events.
courses.prerequisites: junior/senior standing or instructor's consent.  May be repeated for credit

courses.course_description: Principles and processes of importance in the field of nuclear technology.

courses.course_name: Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Engineering I
courses.course_description: (same as ECE 4030). Engineering principles of nuclear power systems, primarily for the production of electrical energy.
Properties of materials for reactor components; radiation damage and corrosion; metallurgy of reactor materials.
courses.prerequisites: upper division or graduate standing in Physical Sciences or Engineering, or instructor's consent

courses.course_description: Principles/applications of nuclear techniques in solution of bioenvironmental problems. Uses of nuclear methods in studies of water/air pollution, biology, medicine, pesticides, geochemistry, ecological transport. Lectures, laboratory.
Basic plasma physics, principles of thermonuclear fusion, plasma confinement and heating, and devices.
courses.prerequisites: senior standing in Engineering or Science or instructor's consent

courses.course_description: Principles of heat transport in nuclear reactors. Brief review of the theory of flow coast down and convective heat transfer. Heat transfer loop experiments on flow coast down, steady state and transient forced convection heat transfer, boiling heat transfer.
Nuclear reactor heat generation and removal; nuclear reactor coolants; analysis of nuclear reactor power plants.
Principles and utilization of thermoelectric, thermionic, photovoltaic, magnetohydrodynamic generators and fuel cells.
(same as ECE 4550; cross-leveled with NU_ENG 7375, ECE 7550). Equations of plasma physics, interaction of waves and plasmas; plasma sheaths and oscillations;   measurements and applications.
An introduction to natural and engineered particulate systems.

(same as ECE 4570; cross-leveled with NU_ENG 7382, ECE 7570). Introduction to lasers, from both a conceptual viewpoint and from the application of Maxwell's equation, to develop the optical theory for lasers.

(same as CHEM 4600). Principles and application of radiation detectors and analyzers: ionization, Geiger-Muller, proportional, liquid and solid scintillation, semiconductor, pulse height analyzers, coincidence circuits, data reduction, tracer applications, activation analysis. Lectures, laboratory.

courses.course_name: Topics in Nuclear Science and Engineering
courses.course_description: Current and new developments in nuclear engineering.

This course will start with an introduction into medical ethics then transitions into research procedures with humans and animals. This course will cover research ethics, professional conduct, authorship, publishing, and plagiarism.

courses.course_name: Special Problems in Nuclear Science and Engineering
courses.course_description: Special Problems in Nuclear Science and Engineering.

courses.course_name: Seminar in Nuclear Science and Engineering
courses.course_description: Reviews of investigations and projects of importance in nuclear engineering.

Introduction of methods and procedures for safe handling of radioisotopes in the research laboratory. Intensive lecture and laboratory training sessions designed for persons planning to use radioisotopes at the University.

(same as RA_SCI 7303). Types and origins of radiation; radiation detection and measurement; radiation interactions; shielding; dose calculations; federal, state and local regulations; and procedures for safe uses of radiation. Laboratory experiments in radiation measurements and protection.

Introductory topics in nuclear engineering. Atomic and nuclear physics; nuclear reactor principles under steady-state and transient conditions; heat removal; shielding; instrumentation; power generation; fusion.

(cross-leveled with NU_ENG 7306). Applies ordinary and partial differential equations to engineering problems; Fourier's series; determinants and matrices; Laplace transforms; analog computer techniques.

courses.course_name: Nuclear Science for Engineering for Secondary Science Teachers
courses.course_description: This one-week course is for high school science and math teachers, and provides basic of nuclear scheme concepts and their applications, types of radiation (including radiation detection and protection), and industrial, medical and nuclear power generation application.
courses.prerequisites: instructor's consent; actively engaged in STEM teaching at the secondary level

courses.course_description: (same as ECE 7020). Analysis of present energy usage in Missouri, USA and the world, evaluation of emerging energy technologies and trends for the future. Economics and environmental impact   of the developed technologies.

(same as PHYSCS 7190, BIOL_EN 7480 and CHEM 7490). Undergraduate/graduate level course offered every winter semester for students from Physics, Chemistry, Engineering and Medical Departments and consists of lectures or laboratory demonstrations, two midterm and one final exam. Graduate students will submit a term paper.
courses.prerequisites: PHYSCS 2760 and CHEM 1320 or equivalent and instructor's consent

courses.course_description: Not for engineering students. Lecture, demonstration; describes physical environment, energy, power plants, nuclear reactors; radioactivity, its biological effects; health physics measures, rad-waste disposal; nuclear safeguards, nuclear explosives, societal implications.
(same as BIO_SC 7328, RADIOL 7328, and V_M_S 7328). Concepts of ionizing radiations, their actions on matter through effects on simple chemical systems, biological molecules, cell, organisms, man.
courses.prerequisites: Sciences/Engineering; one course in Biological Sciences and Physics/Chemistry; or instructor's consent

courses.course_name: Science and Technology of Terrorism and Counter Terrorism
courses.course_description: Terrorism has been a familiar tool of political conflict, and it has assumed greater importance during the past twenty years. This subject has been treated by political scientists in various forms, but the scientific and technological aspects of different forms of terrorism cannot be found in a single place. It is important for persons who propose counter measures to understand the basics of different types of terrorism such as for instance the nature of chemical agents, their properties such as toxicity, etc. in order to build better defense systems.

courses.course_name: Nonproliferation Issues for Weapons of Mass Destruction
courses.course_description: Nonproliferation and impact on technology and world events.
courses.prerequisites: junior or senior standing or instructor's consent

courses.course_description: (same as ECE 7335).  This course provides an overview of nuclear materials management and safeguards, including physical protection systems, material accounting and control, monitoring, and regulatory issues.
Principles and processes of importance in the field of nuclear technology.

courses.course_name: Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Engineering I
courses.course_description: (same as ECE 7030). Engineering principles of nuclear power systems, primarily for the production of electrical energy.
Properties of materials for reactor components; radiation damage and corrosion; metallurgy of reactor materials.
courses.prerequisites: upper division or graduate standing in Physical Sciences or Engineering, or instructor's consent

courses.course_description: Principles/applications of nuclear techniques in solution of bioenvironmental problems. Uses of nuclear methods in studies of water/air pollution, biology, medicine, pesticides, geochemistry, ecological transport. Lectures, laboratory.
Basic plasma physics, principles of thermonuclear fusion, plasma confinement and heating, and devices.
courses.prerequisites: graduate standing in Engineering or Science or instructor's consent

courses.course_description: Principles of heat transport in nuclear reactors. Brief review of the theory of flow coast down and convective heat transfer. Heat transfer loop experiments on flow coast down, steady state and transient forced convection heat transfer, boiling heat transfer.
Nuclear reactor heat generation and removal; nuclear reactor coolants; analysis of nuclear reactor power plants.
Principles and utilization of thermoelectric, thermionic, photovoltaic, magnetohydrodynamic generators and fuel cells.
(same as ECE 7550; cross-leveled with NU_ENG 4375, ECE 4550). Equations of plasma physics, interaction of waves and plasmas; plasma sheaths and oscillations; measurements and applications.
An introduction to natural and engineered particulate systems.

(same as ECE 7570; cross-leveled with NU_ENG 4382, ECE 4570). An introductory course in lasers. The course treats the subject from both a conceptual viewpoint and from the application of Maxwell's equations, to develop the optical theory for lasers. The course includes approximately 10 class-room hours of laboratory work with lasers.

Principles and application of radiation detectors and analyzers: ionization, Geiger-Muller, proportional, liquid and solid scintillation, semiconductor, pulse height analyzers, coincidence circuits, data reduction, tracer applications, activation analysis. Lectures, laboratory.
Fundamentals of radiation interactions stressing neutron and gamma radiation transport; ray theory, removal theory, multi-group transport shield design principles.
Analytical methods for designing fast breeder reactor systems. Graded on a S/U basis only.
courses.prerequisites: NU_ENG 8412, NU_ENG 8432, NU_ENG 8451 or instructor's consent

courses.course_name: Advanced Topics in Nuclear Science and Engineering
courses.course_description: Advanced developments in nuclear engineering.

courses.course_name: Problems in Nuclear Science and Engineering
courses.course_description: Supervised investigation in nuclear engineering to be presented in the form of a report.

courses.course_name: Research in Nuclear Science and Engineering
courses.course_description: Independent investigation in nuclear engineering to be presented as a thesis. Graded on an S/U basis only.

Covers the nuclear fuel cycle from mine through enrichment, fuel element burn-up reactor physics, chemical reprocessing, waste disposal, with special emphasis on the newer proliferation-resistant fuel cycles.
courses.prerequisites: NU_ENG 4346 or NU_ENG 4305 and instructor's consent

courses.course_name: Applied Topics in Medical Physics and Health Physics
courses.course_description: Directed observations and experience in scientific aspects of daily operations in nuclear medicine, diagnostic radiology, radiotherapy and health physics.
Application of reactor physics principals to operation of and experiments with the University of Missouri Research Reactor. Neutron activation analysis, instrumentation, reactivity evaluation.
Advanced experiments to measure diffusion length, Fermi age, material buckling, transfer function, neutron spectrum and other reactor characteristics. Reactor simulation with an analog computer.

courses.course_name: Clinical and Research Application in Medical and Health Physics
courses.course_description: To give students an understanding of the range of clinical practice and medical research involving the practice and nuclear physics/engineering.
courses.prerequisites: NU_ENG 8409 and NU_ENG 4303, college calculus or equivalent and calculus based physics

courses.course_name: State Variable Methods in Automatic Control
courses.course_description: (same as CH_ENG 8780, ECE 8780, and MAE 8780). State variables for continuous and discrete-time dynamic control systems; controllability and observability; optimal control of linear systems.
courses.prerequisites: CH_ENG 4370, ECE 4310, MAE 4730 or instructor's consent

courses.course_description: Theory/applications of radiation interaction processes. Reviews nuclear physics concepts; radioactive decay; sources/ spectra of ionizing radiation; collision mechanisms for changed particles, electromagnetic radiation, neutrons for interaction with matter.
Nuclear reactions; nuclear fission; introduces neutron transport; diffusion and slowing down of neutrons; steady-state homogeneous and heterogeneous reactor theory.
Linear and non-linear reactor kinetics; perturbation theory; temperature and fission product effects; control rod theory; transport theory.

Principles of radiation pulse analysis with emphasis on applications. Radiation detection devices; amplifying, shaping and discrimination circuits; nuclear pulse analysis; automated data analysis systems. Lectures and lab.
Fundamentals of radiation interactions stressing neutron and gamma radiation transport; ray theory, removal theory, multi-group transport shield design principles.

Basis and applications of conventional and microscopic radiation dosimetry. Dose concepts and quantities; biological dose-response models; dose measurement principles; photon, charged particle, and neutron dosimetry.
Engineering topics from reactor heat transfer and thermal stresses, fuel cycle analysis, power plant thermodynamics, shielding, and reactor safety analysis.
courses.prerequisites: NU_ENG 8411 or NU_ENG 4346, or instructor's consent

courses.course_description: (same as MAE 8220). Mechanics of flawed structure. Concepts include Griffith theory, Barenblatt's theory, Irwin analysis, energy analysis of cracked bodies, fracture toughness testing, plane strain, plane stress, transition temperature concepts, subcritical flaw growth.

Principles and applications of X-ray production and interactions. Images production concepts including X-ray film, intensifying screens, grids, fluoroscopy, image intensification and television monitors. Image quality analysis and assessment.
courses.prerequisites: NU_ENG 8409 or equivalent or instructor's consent

courses.course_description: Principles and applications of radiation producing units, exposure and dose measurements, and calibration. External beam physics parameters and application to fixed field and rotational field treatment planning.
courses.prerequisites: NU_ENG 8409 or equivalent or instructor's consent

courses.course_name: Fracture and Fatigue Prevention in Engineering Practice
courses.course_description: Practical design problems. Introduction to retrofit design, maintenance, product improvement and new design from a fatigue and fracture prevention philosophy. Fail safe and safe life designs are presented.

(same as ECE 8020). Phenomenology and theory of superconductivity; cryogenic practice; metallurgy of superconducting elements, alloys and compounds. Applications, present and prospective. Graded on an S/U basis only.
Applies numerical analysis and digital computation to topics from multi-group diffusion theory, transport theory, reactor kinetics, reactor thermal hydraulics, radiation shielding, reactor safety.
The physical principles of MRI and ultrasound including clinical instrumentation, artifacts in images, biological effects and quality control. Images obtained with both techniques will be presented.

Plasma stability theory, charged particle diffusion, slowing down of charged particles, interaction of radiation with matter, direct energy conversion using charged particles, and engineering considerations.
courses.prerequisites: NU_ENG 4353 and NU_ENG 4375 or PHYSCS 8450 or instructor's consent

courses.course_description: Physical principles, statistics of radionuclide decay and highlights into the most current instrumentation to utilize invivo radionuclides for both diagnostic imaging and therapy. Also includes brachy therapy.

courses.course_name: Growth, Characterization and Appl. of Diamond and Related Materials
courses.course_description: This course explores the development of diamond films. Discussion of other wide band-gap materials are covered. Topics include Chemistry of Diamond Growth, Thermodynamics, Nucleation, Methods of Growth, Methods of Impurity Control, Characterization and Modification, Doping, and Applications.
The Boltzmann equation; general properties and solution; numerical methods of solving the transport equation; neutron thermalization and neutron spectra.
courses.prerequisites: NU_ENG 8412; MATH 4940, MATH 4300, or instructor's consent

courses.course_description: Analytical methods for designing fast breeder reactor systems. Graded on a S/U basis only.
courses.prerequisites: NU_ENG 8412, NU_ENG 8432, NU_ENG 8451 or instructor's consent

courses.course_description: Theory and applications of radiation protection and health physics. Radiation dosimetry methods and calculations, shielding evaluations, equipment surveys and inspection, environmental monitoring, radiation standards and regulations and administration presented.

courses.course_name: Research in Nuclear Science and Engineering
courses.course_description: Independent investigation in nuclear engineering to be presented as a thesis. Graded on an S/U basis only.
